title: Sick on Thanksgiving
content:
Sick on Thanksgiving

This post was written in English (en_US).

I'm lying on my couch in my San Francisco apartment trying to recover from the sickness I acquired. The last few days have been rough! Being sick is something I don't like to experience but here we are.

Since I couldn't return to Nebraska this year for the holiday, I had plans to do a Friendsgiving.

Everyone is enjoying themselves and having a grand old time.

It would be selfish of me to show up sick, and miserable, and risk getting people sick. I know people understand, but I don't like to disappoint others.

I am grateful for a few things:

My Parents

Even though I couldn't return to Nebraska, I am very grateful for them. They have been very supportive in various aspects of life. I know they miss me and they wish I could move back. They love how I've branched off to live in a different place. I miss them a lot but I will see them soon!

My Friend Evan

My friend Evan was so kind enough for me to bring me crackers as I was struggling yesterday. He's a keeper! Those crackers brought me back to life. I'm so appreciative to have Evan in my life.

Evan even walked me to McDonald's this morning making sure I got a light meal. McDonald's was closed. :( I just wanted two burritos.

My Friends Sarah and Mike

My friend Sarah has been amazing over the years especially when I moved to Sacramento. She has helped me so much in getting used to California living and of course, having to put up with my shenanigans.

Mike is a great friend as well. He helped me guide my career to where it is now! He is a great person to have an amazing conversation with. I love talking about ethics with him and anything related to tech.

I miss them both!

Alone Time

Being sick allowed me to do nothing, which is not bad. I ordered some soup in hopes of making me feel better sooner. I probably should watch a movie instead of doom-scrolling. I deserve to enjoy myself a little. Maybe I will code and work on my website and working on an API.

Homebrew Website Club

I am grateful I hung out remotely at Homebrew Website Club yesterday! I didn't participate as much as I wanted but I still made the effort to attend. There was some great conversation happening! Shoutout to Tracy and Angelo for hanging out and tucking me in virtually when I finally crashed.

Happy Holidays.

title: Re: 15 Books with the Most Impact
content:
Re: 15 Books with the Most Impact

Books

This post was written in English (en_US).

Tracy nominated me a while ago (more like July) to share my list(s) of books that have impacted me. Reiterating what Tracy wrote, many of these books had their moment with me and others still hold strong to me.

I won't go too in-depth for some of these for various reasons. I also don't wan't to give too many spoilers.

Books:

A Thousand Splendid Suns - Khaled Hosseini

Maus / Maus II - Art Spiegelman

A graphic novel where Spiegelman interviews his father about his experiences as a Polish Jew and Holocaust survivor. *I really enjoyed the various themes in the book.

This is a must read

1984 - George Orwell

This taught me many lessons and how eerie this period of time is currently. I'm pretty scared for what's to come.

The Odyssey - Homer

Many of the themes taught me some important lessons.

In The Hot Zone - Kevin Sites

This wasn't my favorite book but it made me aware of various wars and situations happening beyond Iraq.

Lady of the Lake - Sir Walter Scott

Yeruldelgger - Ian Manook (French)

This book me realize I can actually read French.

Ryan White My Own Story - Ryan White

Ryan White has always been an inspiration to me as I have in various periods of my life been involved with bringing awareness about HIV/AIDS. It fascinated me how well-versed Ryan was and his outlook on life as he was very unlucky getting the virus from tainted blood products.

Le Gone du ChaÃ¢ba - Azouz Begag (French)

Le Gone du ChaÃ¢ba (The Kid of the Chaaba), translated into English as Shantytown Kid by Naima Wolf.

I love this book as it shows the struggles of balancing two different cultures - the country you live in and the culture at home. This book understood me in various ways as I struggled to balance US life and my Mexican culture.

My French Professor gave me this book as a graduation gift.

Remaking Manhood: Stories From the Front Lines of Change - Mark Greene

I read this book right before I graduated college. Being a male teacher is very important as many students don't have a good male role model at home. I made it a goal in my teaching to help my students not fall for certain behaviors.

This book also helped me reevaluate my relationships and look deep inside of me.

Here's a good link related to Remaking Manhood

Winning the War On War - Joshua S. Goldstein

I minored in International Studies and this book really opened me up to deeper issues that continue to exist.

Constructive Living - David K. Reynolds

Although this book wasn't the solution to many of my problems during some very dark times, it has helped me address them and find the right direction. It has helped me get out of the rut.

Journey To The Future: A Roadmap for Success for Youth - Consuelo Castillo Kickbusch (Author)

This book has helped me in various ways to get where I am today. Consuela is a great presenter!

The New Koreans: The Story of a Nation - Michael Breen

en

This month's IndieWeb Carnival focuses on self-expression. Everyone and anyone is welcome to participate! I love reading posts in different languages!

Send me a webmention or email me at pablo[at]lifeofpablo.com to submit your posts. I will create a round up post and i will update this blog post with the replies I receive!

What is self-expression?

That depends

self-expression (noun)

self-exÂ·â€‹presÂ·â€‹sion ËŒself-ik-Ëˆspre-shÉ™n

The expression of one's personality : assertion of one's individual traits

Self-expression comes in various forms. It manifests differently in every person. There is no single route to how people develop how they become. People express themselves loudly, quietly, non-verbally, or in any other way. Many things influence us in our lives. The environment we grew up in influences how we present to the world. Our cultural backgrounds, the countries we've lived in, the languages we speak, or the type of supportive friends we have in our lives are all the ingredients that build the recipe for who we become and how we share our personalities with the world.

For me, I love speaking languages! I love playing games in French and being super duper competitive. I love reading in Spanish!

I grew up in a Mexican household which has greatly influenced my ways of self-expression. I love speaking with more emotion at home and being surrounded by people with my cultural background. An example of this is when I am angry, I will cuss in Spanish like no other. I feel so much better after letting it all out. This Instagram reel in Spanish will tell you what I mean.

The Mexican culture influences my American side and vice versa. I would consider myself very expressive in English. Ever since I was a kid, I loved saying, "That's so cute" or "That flower is so pretty." Sharing your emotions is very beautiful. Don't be afraid of saying things out loud like this. Fuck that toxic masculinity garbage!

I love blogging and journaling. I love having a journal - getting lost in my thoughts while jotting them down on beautiful lined or dotted paper on a park bench or sitting crisscross applesauce on the top of a building in San Francisco. I love sharing my thoughts publicly blogging or quietly on paper. Not all forms of expression have to be public. Self-expression also includes time when it's you and only you involved. This includes recording audio notes, coding your new blog engine, or building an arcade cabinet. Alone time is self-expression.

As I've become older, I've stopped caring as much about what people perceive of me (or what I thought people perceived of me) in the things that interest me. Self-expression is about how comfortable you can be with yourself. It comes down to loving yourself more every day. I love dressing in bright colors, especially on a nice sunny day. It makes me feel great and brightens my mood. Heck, find me wearing the brightest pink shirt out in public in the streets of San Francisco.

How you view self-expression is open to interpretation. How do you self-express?

Here are some questions to get you started to get the juices flowing:

How do you present yourself to the world?

What does self-expression do for you?

Do you use self-expression as a coping mechanism?

What has been your journey to becoming a more expressive version of yourself?

If your family culture is different from the country that you live in, how do you balance your self-expression? Are they intertwined?

title: I'm using traefik on my infrastructure.
content:
I'm using traefik on my infrastructure.

Traefik Logo

This post was written in English (en_US).

Some Background

For a few weeks, I've been thinking about using another reverse-proxy service just to try something new.

Since I launched my docker mono-repository that hosts my entire infrastructure, I've used nginx as my primary reverse-proxy. I was using Jason WIlder's nginx proxy to expose my applications to the web from the virtual machine.

Now I have transitioned to using traefik. It was very easy to add labels specific to traefik to my services in my docker compose file.

In my docker compose setup, I used Let's Encrypt for SSL certificates in both nginx and traefik.

Just like with any major change, I was worried about downtime but I took the risk and I tested out *lifeofpablo.com * and some other subdomains. Once I labeled the items with traefik specific items, and redeployed, it worked great! Once I looked around for anything out of place, I went back and added traefik labels to the rest of my containers.

nginx

Within the docker file, nginx-proxy would use environmental variables to route outside of the machine to the domain or subdomain that the DNS will point to.

environment: VIRTUAL_HOST: service.lifeofpablo.com LETSENCRYPT_HOST: service.lifeofpablo.com

traefik

Instead of using environmental variables explicitly, traefik uses labels to route. In this example, I'm using my the service korea.lifeofpablo.com (korea) as the service being proxied.

I simply matched the service name, korea as this is the name of the container in Docker and for the host, I used korea.lifeofpablo.com.

labels: - "traefik.http.routers.korea.rule=Host(`korea.lifeofpablo.com`)" - "traefik.http.routers.korea.entrypoints=websecure" - "traefik.http.routers.korea.tls.certresolver=myresolver"

Future

What I have in mind for the future of my infrastructure with traefik is to control authentication. I want to use Zitadel to add authentication to services I have to simply experiment. This experimentation will be key as I continue planning the rebuild of my website. I want my future version of my website to be the center of my internet presence and be able to connect easily with my services.

Just like with any major change, I was worried about downtime but I took the risk and I tested out *lifeofpablo.com * and some other subdomains. Once I labeled the items with traefik specific items, and redeployed, it worked great! Once I looked around for anything out of place, I went back and added traefik labels to the rest of my containers.

nginx

Within the docker file, nginx-proxy would use environmental variables to route outside of the machine to the domain or subdomain that the DNS will point to.

environment: VIRTUAL_HOST: service.lifeofpablo.com LETSENCRYPT_HOST: service.lifeofpablo.com

traefik

Instead of using environmental variables explicitly, traefik uses labels to route. In this example, I'm using my the service korea.lifeofpablo.com (korea) as the service being proxied.

I simply matched the service name, korea as this is the name of the container in Docker and for the host, I used korea.lifeofpablo.com.

labels: - "traefik.http.routers.korea.rule=Host(`korea.lifeofpablo.com`)" - "traefik.http.routers.korea.entrypoints=websecure" - "traefik.http.routers.korea.tls.certresolver=myresolver"

Future

What I have in mind for the future of my infrastructure with traefik is to control authentication. I want to use Zitadel to add authentication to services I have to simply experiment. This experimentation will be key as I continue planning the rebuild of my website. I want my future version of my website to be the center of my internet presence and be able to connect easily with my services.

title: What makes a good friend?
content:
What makes a good friend?

Group of Friends

This post was written in English (en_US).

This post is a response to my blog post. I am answering question #91: What makes a good friend?

What makes a good friend? That's a great question. I think everyone has a different definition of what makes a good friend. I will share mine.

One of the most important things to understand about friendship is point's of view. We don't have to always agree with each other. We do need to be able to listen, process and be able to provide counter points of view in a respectable manner. Allowing time to process is important instead of reacting as the default.

One of the most important qualities of a good friend is being supportive. I'm very fortunate to have friends who are supportive and emotionally connected. We check in with each other, we talk about our emotions, we talk about our problems. As men, we are human and we should talk about what's happening to our lives. This is 2025.

A good friend will always make an effort to stay in touch especially when you live far away from each other. This is a two way streak. One person can't solely be the one actively reaching out. It's okay if you go a little while without talking, just don't let your friendship die out. Life gets busy but we can't forget who our friends are.

What makes a good friend?

This post was written in English (en_US).

Today, I turn 30 years old. Woohoo! I guess Iâ€™m no longer a 20-something-year-old. These last 10 years have flown by quickly but man, have they been memorable. Itâ€™s a tad bitter sweet. The positive overtakes the negative by a long shot. I canâ€™t stop the aging process. If only it were that easy!

Honestly, at this very moment, I donâ€™t feel any different. I still feel energetic and craving adventure. I think these song lyrics from T-Swizzle describe how I feel.

(Hey!) I don't know about you But I'm feeling twenty-two

In hindsight, looking at myself in the mirror more recently, I notice my facial hair is starting to turn white. Nothing like a fresh shave that still makes me look young and boyish. I must being doing something right with my skin routine (and maybe good genes from my parents)!

Reflections

I reflect on the growth Iâ€™ve had since I entered my 20s. My 20s were about

Learning

Falling and rising

Going on adventures.

Loved ones

I learned some great lessons along the way. Some lessons were not so easy to swallow. Man, did I learn. There are so many things I know now that I wish a 20-year-old me knew. One of the things I wish he knew was, â€œLove yourself more!â€ I do love myself more than ever. Iâ€™m happier with who Iâ€™ve become. Iâ€™m not done learning who I become. I donâ€™t think that ever stops. There were many moments in life when I hit my absolute lowest. Those are moments Iâ€™m not proud of. While I did manage to get myself out of them, I did come back stronger. Another lesson here - ask for help and use the resources available to you. Youâ€™re not alone, I promise.

Take risks! Take more! I'm thrilled to have moved to California. I still canâ€™t believe that this guy from Nebraska moved to San Francisco. I was grateful to have gone on so many adventures. I learned so much about myself getting away. Some of my best learning moments have been from strangers and experiences with myself in another country. Who knew you could learn something so new about yourself at 3 am while eating a dÃµner kebab on the streets of Berlin?

When I was in my early 20s, I said something along the lines of, â€œI get to be away from my parents! Freedom!â€ When I was in college, I didnâ€™t want to come home as often, or if I went home to visit, I would not stay for too long. Now more than ever, I miss my parents. Now, I live far away from them. I only get to have home-cooked meals a few times a year. It honestly makes me sad watching them get older. I still need my parents. I do my best to call every day. My relationship with them has been stronger than ever. I am thankful for all the things theyâ€™ve done for me and my siblings

Whoâ€™s cutting the internet onions on here?

Travel

Iâ€™m very fortunate that I traveled a lot in my 20s. I want to thank my parents for taking us to Mexico as a young kid.

Iâ€™ve traveled to Canada, all over Europe, South Korea, Mexico, and various parts of the United States.

Travel Buddies

I got to travel with my favorite travel buddies, Sammy and Manny! We've have gone on some wild adventures. Iâ€™m very happy we stayed friends. Best travel buddies ever!

Best Birthday Ever! - Czech Republic

One of my favorite birthdays was when I was studying abroad in Europe. I visited my friends in the Czech Republic.

Pabloâ€™s 22nd birthday in 2017 in Czech Republic]

Friends

Iâ€™ve made an amazing community of friends. People, I consider my family away from home. Learning from people whom I loved, making friends wherever I go! Iâ€™ve made so many friends.

What goals do I have in my 30s?

There are a lot of things I want to accomplish during my 30s. I have a vision for the next few years! Iâ€™m hopeful I can find the right path to reach my goals

Education

I truly value education. It got me where I am today! I was very fortunate to receive a great public school education. Others also need to have access to a great public school education. We must fight against the privatization of the education system. I want to continue to fight for public education. Public education provided me with so many opportunities.

I am currently doing my masterâ€™s degree at the University of Nebraska Kearney. My goal one day is to teach a class or two at the university level. It would be awesome to guide future teachers and help them be confident with technology use and go beyond 21st-century learning. I do miss being in the classroom.

I would like to receive a PhD.

I also want to improve my programming skills.

Health

Iâ€™m working towards getting in better shape and thinking of long-term health. As I age, I know I wonâ€™t bounce back from injury as quickly. I know I must do everything in my power to take control of my health. Preventative measures are what will keep the hospital away. Mental health is just as important.

Adventures

I want to continue traveling. I want to visit more parts of the world. Ever since I last renewed my passport, the visa pages have been blank. The passport I had in my early twenties was pretty full. Itâ€™s so satisfying to look at the stamps and stickers on each page. I want to take my parents on a fun adventure as well

Startup

Iâ€™ve been helping a friend with a startup and launching an idea that we have. I am hopeful this year will be great!

Financial Independence

I want to make smarter choices with money. Iâ€™ve been reading up on financial literature to become better with money. Times are changing, and I must keep up with inflation, changing markets, AI, etc.

Looking Forward

Overall, things are finally clicking. Iâ€™m excited for whatâ€™s to come and all the things to learn. I will reevaluate and reprioritize many things in life.

What have you learned in your 30s?

How am I celebrating my birthday?

Luckily, I live in San Francisco, so thereâ€™s a lot to do! I will be celebrating the entire weekend with my friends in San Francisco! So stoked to watch Drag Disco with Trixie Mattel! Letâ€™s put on some pink clothes and dance into my 30s!

title: â€˜Nobody wants a robot to read them a story!â€™ The creatives and academics rejecting AI â€“ at work and at home
content:
The novelist Ewan Morrison was alarmed, though amused, to discover he had written a book called Nine Inches Pleases a Lady. Intrigued by the limits of generative artificial intelligence (AI), he had asked ChatGPT to give him the names of the 12 novels he had written. â€œIâ€™ve only written nine,â€ he says. â€œAlways eager to please, it decided to invent three.â€ The â€œnine inchesâ€ from the fake title it hallucinated was stolen from a filthy Robert Burns poem. â€œI just distrust these systems when it comes to truth,â€ says Morrison. He is yet to write Nine Inches â€“ â€œor its sequel, Eighteen Inchesâ€, he laughs. His actual latest book, For Emma, imagining AI brain-implant chips, is about the human costs of technology.

Morrison keeps an eye on the machines, such as OpenAIâ€™s ChatGPT, and their capabilities, but he refuses to use them in his own life and work. He is one of a growing number of people who are actively resisting: people who are terrified of the power of generative AI and its potential for harm and donâ€™t want to feed the beast; those who have just decided that itâ€™s a bit rubbish, and more trouble than itâ€™s worth; and those who simply prefer humans to robots.

Go online, and itâ€™s easy to find AI proponents who dismiss refuseniks as ignorant luddites â€“ or worse, smug hipsters. I possibly fall into both camps, given that I have decidedly Amish interests (board games, gardening, animal husbandry) and write for the Guardian. Friends swear by ChatGPT for parenting advice, and I know someone who uses it all day for work in her consultancy business, but I havenâ€™t used it since playing around after it launched in 2022. Admittedly ChatGPT might have done a better job, but this piece was handcrafted using organic words from my artisanal writing studio. (OK, I mean bed.) I could have assumed my intervieweesâ€™ thoughts from plundering their social media posts and research papers, as ChatGPT would have done, but it was far more enjoyable to pick up the phone and talk, human to human. Two of my interviewees were interrupted by their pets, and each made me laugh in some way (full disclosure: AI then transcribed the noise).

View image in fullscreen Ewan Morrison: â€˜Itâ€™s a product of venture capital gone nutsâ€™ Photograph: Roberto Ricciuti/Getty Images

On X, where Morrison sometimes clashes with AI enthusiasts, a common insult is â€œdecelâ€ (decelerationist), but it makes him laugh when people think heâ€™s the one who isnâ€™t keeping up. â€œThereâ€™s nothing [that stops] accelerationism more than failure to deliver on what you promised. Hitting a brick wall is a good way to decelerate,â€ he says. One recent study found that AI answered more than 60% of queries inaccurately.

Morrison was drawn into the argument by what he would now call â€œalarmist fears about the potential for superintelligence and runaway AI. The more Iâ€™ve got into it, the more I realise thatâ€™s a fiction thatâ€™s been dangled before the investors of the world, so theyâ€™ll invest billions â€“ in fact, half a trillion â€“ into this quest for artificial superintelligence. Itâ€™s a fantasy, a product of venture capital gone nuts.â€

There are also copyright violations â€“ generative AI is trained on existing material â€“ that threaten him as a writer, and his wife, screenwriter Emily Ballou. In the entertainment industry, he says, people are using â€œAI algorithms to determine what projects get the go-ahead, and that means weâ€™re stuck remaking the past. The algorithms say â€˜More of the sameâ€™, because itâ€™s all they can do.â€

I read because I want to understand how somebody sees the world. Thereâ€™s no â€˜somebodyâ€™ in the synthetic text-extruding machines

Morrison says he has a long list of complaints. â€œTheyâ€™ve been stacking up over the past few years.â€ He is concerned about the job losses (Bill Gates recently predicted AI would lead to a two-day work week). Then there are â€œtech addiction, the ecological impact, the damage to the education system â€“ 92% of students are now using AIâ€. He worries about the way tech companies spy on us to make AI personalised, and is horrified at AI-enabled weapons being used in Ukraine. â€œI find that ethically revolting.â€

Others cite similar reasons for not using AI. April Doty, an audiobook narrator, is appalled at the environmental cost â€“ the computational power required to perform an AI search and answer is huge. â€œIâ€™m infuriated that you canâ€™t turn off the AI overviews in Google search,â€ she says. â€œWhenever you look anything up now youâ€™re basically torching the planet.â€ She has started to use other search engines. â€œBut, more and more, weâ€™re surrounded by it, and thereâ€™s no off switch. That makes me angry.â€ Where she still can, she says, â€œIâ€™m opting out of using AI.â€

View image in fullscreen Illustration: Kaan Illustration/The Guardian

In her own field, she is concerned about the number of books that are being â€œreadâ€ by machines. Audible, the Amazon-owned audiobook provider, has just announced it will allow publishers to create audiobooks using its AI technology. â€œI donâ€™t know anybody who wants a robot to read them a story, but I am concerned that it is going to ruin the experience to the point where people donâ€™t want to subscribe to audiobook platforms any more,â€ says Doty. She hasnâ€™t lost jobs to AI yet but other colleagues have, and chances are, it will happen. AI models canâ€™t â€œnarrateâ€, she says. â€œNarrators donâ€™t just read words; they sense and express the feelings beneath the words. AI can never do this job because it requires decades of experience in being a human being.â€

Emily M Bender, professor of linguistics at the University of Washington and co-author of a new book, The AI Con, has many reasons why she doesnâ€™t want to use large language models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT. â€œBut maybe the first one is that Iâ€™m not interested in reading something that nobody wrote,â€ she says. â€œI read because I want to understand how somebody sees something, and thereâ€™s no â€˜somebodyâ€™ inside the synthetic text-extruding machines.â€ Itâ€™s just a papier-mache made from lots of different peopleâ€™s words, she says.

Does she feel she is being â€œleft behindâ€, as AI enthusiasts would say? â€œNo, not at all. My reaction to that is, â€˜Whereâ€™s everybody going?â€™â€ She laughs as if to say: nowhere good.

â€œWhen we turn to synthetic media rather than authentic media, we are losing out on human connection,â€ says Bender. â€œThatâ€™s both at a personal level â€“ what we get out of connecting to other people â€“ and in terms of strength of community.â€ She cites Chris Gilliard, the surveillance and privacy researcher. â€œHe made the very important point that you can see this as a technological move by the companies to isolate us from each other, and to set things up so that all of our interactions are mediated through their products. We donâ€™t need that, for us or our communities.â€

Despite Benderâ€™s well-publicised position â€“ she has long been a high-profile critic of LLMs â€“ incredibly, she has seen students turn in AI-generated work. â€œThatâ€™s very sad.â€ She doesnâ€™t want to be policing, or even blaming, students. â€œMy job is to make sure students understand why it is that turning to a large language model is depriving themselves of a learning opportunity, in terms of what they would get out of doing the work.â€

Does she think people should boycott generative AI? â€œBoycott suggests organised political action, and sure, why not?â€ she says. â€œI also think that people are individually better off if they donâ€™t use them.â€

I almost feel I have no choice but to use AI at this point. I might have to put morals aside

Some people have so far held out, but are reluctantly realising they may end up using it. Tom, who works in IT for the government, doesnâ€™t use AI in his tech work, but found colleagues were using it in other ways. Promotion is partly decided on annual appraisals they have to write, and he had asked a manager whose appraisal had impressed him how heâ€™d done it, thinking heâ€™d spent days on it. â€œHe said, â€˜I just spent 10 minutes â€“ I used ChatGPT,â€™â€ Tom recalls. â€œHe suggested I should do the same, which I donâ€™t agree with. I made that point, and he said, â€˜Well, youâ€™re probably not going to get anywhere unless you do.â€™â€ Using AI would feel like cheating, but Tom worries refusing to do so now puts him at a disadvantage. â€œI almost feel like I have no choice but to use it at this point. I might have to put morals aside.â€

Others, despite their misgivings, limit how they use it, and only for specific tasks. Steve Royle, professor of cell biology at the University of Warwick, uses ChatGPT for the â€œgrunt workâ€ of writing computer code to analyse data. â€œBut thatâ€™s really the limit. I donâ€™t want it to generate code from scratch. When you let it do that, you spend way more time debugging it afterwards. My view is, itâ€™s a waste of time if you let it try and do too much for you.â€ Accurate or not, he also worries that if he becomes too reliant on AI, his coding skills will atrophy. â€œThe AI enthusiasts say, â€˜Donâ€™t worry, eventually nobody will need to know anything.â€™ I donâ€™t subscribe to that.â€

View image in fullscreen Justine Bateman: â€˜Itâ€™s one of the worst ideas society has ever come up withâ€™ Photograph: NBC/Nathan Congleton/Getty Images

Part of his job is to write research papers and grant proposals. â€œI absolutely will not use it for generating any text,â€ says Royle. â€œFor me, in the process of writing, you formulate your ideas, and by rewriting and editing, it really crystallises what you want to say. Having a machine do that is not what itâ€™s about.â€

Generative AI, says film-maker and writer Justine Bateman, â€œis one of the worst ideas society has ever come up withâ€. She says she despises how it incapacitates us. â€œTheyâ€™re trying to convince people they canâ€™t do the things theyâ€™ve been doing easily for years â€“ to write emails, to write a presentation. Your daughter wants you to make up a bedtime story about puppies â€“ to write that for you.â€ We will get to the point, she says with a grim laugh, â€œthat you will essentially become just a skin bag of organs and bones, nothing else. You wonâ€™t know anything and you will be told repeatedly that you canâ€™t do it, which is the opposite of what life has to offer. Capitulating all kinds of decisions like where to go on vacation, what to wear today, who to date, what to eat. People are already doing this. You wonâ€™t have to process grief, because youâ€™ll have uploaded photos and voice messages from your mother who just died, and then she can talk to you via AI video call every day. One of the ways itâ€™s going to destroy humans, long before thereâ€™s a nuclear disaster, is going to be the emotional hollowing-out of people.â€

We keep moving like zombies towards a world that nobody really wants to live in

She is not interested. â€œIt is the complete opposite direction of where Iâ€™m going as a film-maker and author. Generative AI is like a blender â€“ you put in millions of examples of the type of thing you want and it will give you a Frankenstein spoonful of it.â€ Itâ€™s theft, she says, and regurgitation. â€œNothing original will come out of it, by the nature of what it is. Anyone who uses generative AI, who thinks theyâ€™re an artist, is stopping their creativity.â€

Some studios, such as the animation company Studio Ghibli, have sworn off using AI, but others appear to be salivating at the prospect. In 2023, Dreamworks founder Jeffrey Katzenberg said AI would cut the costs of its animated films by 90%. Bateman thinks audiences will tire of AI-created content. â€œHuman beings will react to this in the way they react to junk food,â€ she says. Deliciously artificial to some, if not nourishing â€“ but many of us will turn off. Last year she set up an organisation, Credo 23, and a film festival, to showcase films made without AI. She likens it to an â€œorganic stamp for films, that tells the audience no AI was used.â€ People, she says, will â€œhunger for something raw, real and humanâ€.

In everyday life, Bateman is trying â€œto be in a parallel universe, where Iâ€™m trying to avoid [AI] as much as possible.â€ Itâ€™s not that she is anti-tech, she stresses. â€œI have a computer science degree, I love tech. I love salt, too, but I donâ€™t put it on everything.â€

In fact, everyone I speak to is a technophile in some way. Doty describes herself as â€œvery tech-forwardâ€, but she adds that she values human connection, which AI is threatening. â€œWe keep moving like zombies towards a world that nobody really wants to live in.â€ Royle codes and runs servers, but also describes himself as a â€œconscientious AI objectorâ€. Bender specialises in computational linguistics and was named by Time as one of the top 100 people in AI in 2023. â€œI am a technologist,â€ she says, â€œbut I believe that technology should be built by communities for their own purposes, rather than by large corporations for theirs.â€ She also adds, with a laugh: â€œThe Luddites were awesome! I would wear that badge with pride.â€ Morrison, too, says: â€œI quite like the Luddites â€“ people standing up to protect the jobs that keep their families and their communities alive.â€

content:
Iâ€™m turning 40 later this year, and Iâ€™ve been thinking about the reality that Iâ€™m approaching â€œhalfwayâ€ through my statistically projected lifespan. But Iâ€™m not having a crisis about my personal life choicesâ€¦ instead Iâ€™m having a crisis of generational impotence. Iâ€™m tired of waiting for my generationâ€™s turn, which I am less and less convinced will come in time to make a difference, especially since GenZ seems to be going conservative ğŸ˜‘

Outer South by Conor Oberst and the Mystic Valley Band

I finally got letters back from two of my reps:

Senator Murray, 74yo and in office since 1993 when I was in third grade, wants me to know that she â€œremain[s] committed to continuing to work with [her] colleagues on both sides of the aisle to find ways to make progress on immigration reform.â€ Thank you for your complacency Senator. I donâ€™t know how immigration progress will be made with isolationist Nazis tbh ğŸ§ I donâ€™t get why Dems are taking conservative immigration stances when in my mind the problem is we are too strict on immigration, and should let in more people. There, birth rate â€œcrisisâ€ solved too! What I want to know now is, what are the Senatorâ€™s plans for retirement?

Representative DelBeneâ€™s office thinks I â€œmay be pleased to know that [she] joined [her] Democratic colleagues in sending a letter to President Trump expressing serious concern about Mr. Abrego Garciaâ€™s case and requesting an immediate update on his wellbeing and how the administration plans to ensure his safe return to the United States.â€ I am, in fact, not pleased. I am the opposite of pleased. Is she fucking with me? Does she not go on the Internet? In what world am I satisfied that she signed a strongly worded letter and called it good?

My resentment towards 80yo politicians who wonâ€™t retire and pass their power to the next generation is reaching a rolling boil as the Democrats in charge apparently donâ€™t have an ounce of urgency left in their moldering bodies. I have to think itâ€™s intentional, especially given the way Nancy and co blocked Millennial AOC from a position of power in favor of an old dude with cancer who just died from it (â€œGerryâ€™s a young 74, cancer notwithstandingâ€ ğŸ™„ğŸ™„ğŸ™„); I think Boomer politicians know how badly theyâ€™ve fucked over everyone younger than them, and they will literally hold power until they die to prevent facing justice. (Yeah Iâ€™m making it generational, theyâ€™ve been demonizing Millennials to avoid looking in the mirror for decades.) They booted 25yo David Hogg from DNC leadership as punishment for suggesting the party should not always support incumbents, making a mockery of DEI principles by using gender equality rules to invalidate his election.

A friend and I just looked it up: Nancy Pelosi was first elected in 1987. She has been in power for basically my entire life. And I am turning 40. Her legacy, in my mind? But itâ€™s time to go home, get some rest, and let someone else have a turn! (Sorry Bernie, I love ya man, but you too!!!)

If youâ€™re already past the actuarial tables, you shouldnâ€™t get to make decisions for the rest of us who are going to live in the world our politicians make for potentially decades. (I expect the Supreme Court will be ultra conservative for the rest of my life because Dems wouldnâ€™t dare trying to expand it.) Be a mentor, yes, please! But give up the power. Normal retirement age is 67. I donâ€™t think itâ€™s ageist to suggest it might be time for someone two decades past retirement age to pass the torch.

Give me a party with energy, give me politicians who fight! Oh, for an opposition party ğŸ¥º I donâ€™t have to agree 100% with them, if theyâ€™d just have some gumption. Give me AOC energy, Shawn Fain energy, Pete Buttigieg (!) energy, Cory Booker energy, Chris Van Hollen energy, Kat Abughazaleh energy. Not whatever this pathetic excuse for â€œleadershipâ€ is. Walz had the energy and they told him to stuff it. Brilliant strategy guys.

Please, please tell me someone is primarying all my Federal reps next election, because I will vote for anyone who shows some semblance of spine ğŸ˜¡

Pabloâ€™s 22nd birthday in 2017 in Czech Republic]

title: learning â€“ Tracy Durnell's Mind Garden
content:
Liked Rob Sheffield on the Joys of the CD, Musicâ€™s Least-Glamorous Format by Rob Sheffield ( Rolling Stone ) Compact discs never had the romance of vinyl or the convenience of MP3s. But theyâ€™re still the ideal format for getting lost inside your music collection.

I still have a CD player in my car so I hung onto my favorite 20-30 albums, and I somewhat regret getting rid of my collection. It wasnâ€™t ever as big as my parentâ€™s, but I had ~50-70 jazz CDs (donated to the local HS music department so hopefully someoneâ€™s still using them) plus probably a hundred albums. Some indie shit I probably couldnâ€™t replace if I wanted (I like to think Iâ€™ve become slightly more thoughtful about what I give away in my wiser 30s ğŸ˜‚).

But to be fair, my listening has shifted a lot since college, so the music I listen to most I donâ€™t have on CD, and I got rid of a bunch of albums that I had kinda outgrown, so maybe itâ€™s not a bad thing. Iâ€™ve only bought one or two CDs a year for the past decade, indie bands I wanted to give some extra support (and listen in the car).

Thereâ€™s something about having a tangible object that makes it easier to flip through your collection and pull out things you havenâ€™t listened to in a while. Growing up I was obsessed with learning to recognize every song that came on, so I was constantly comparing against the back of the CD. I liked looking through the liner art, and had a great visual memory for what the cover of every album was. Now itâ€™s hard for me to remember what artist performed what song â€“ I think that physical object of the jewel case was an anchor point for my memory. I also listen to playlists primarily these days, and know only a single song (or handful) by any given artist.

(Related? Structures of Thought)

I think thereâ€™s a place for both CDs and playlists in a musical library â€“ Iâ€™ve benefitted from both styles of listening. But I do miss my five disc changer from my youthâ€¦ hooked up to massive speakers nearly 3â€² tall in my living room so they could punch some damn volume ğŸ˜‚ (No idea if they were any good or not ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸)

I also think itâ€™s worth remembering we got rid of our CDs for a reasonâ€¦ they do take up a lot of space and jewel cases are shitâ€¦ but now weâ€™ve spent time without them we can recognize what weâ€™ve lost along with them.

I keep thinking about looking up a used CD player, maybe Iâ€™ll actually get around to it once day ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸ğŸ˜‚ Iâ€™m curious how much I would listen to CDs if we upgraded the music system in our car and Bluetooth wasnâ€™t an enormous pain â€“ would I revert to mostly Spotify playlists on my phone? ğŸ¤”

title: Realities, perceived and presented, and their relationship to Truth â€“ Tracy Durnell's Mind Garden
content:
Iâ€™ve been thinking a lot lately about how knowledge doesnâ€™t equal understandingâ€”there are things you can know to be intellectually true, but that doesnâ€™t mean your body or heart has caught up yet. â€¦ You have to prove to your nervous system, choice by choice, that this new way of thinking is actually safeâ€¦ â€” Dipa Halder

+

Crises are moments of intense unpredictability. A crisis is, by definition, a rupture with the recent past, making any projection of the likely future a foolâ€™s game. Screens promise to relieve the discomfort this brings about: the unending stream, the servile virtual assistant, the fully optimized dayâ€”all are designed to make things predictable, to resolve the anxiety of not knowing what could happen next. â€” Mandy Brown

+

we long for the corporeal in a landscape governed by hypotheticals that may or may not evolve into literals. â€” Kyle Raymond Fitzpatrick

+

America has no memory. Pioneering homesteaders, Gold Rushers, post-war company men with green lawns, Steve Jobs, ALL OUR GREAT MYTHOLOGIES, REALLY, NECESSITATE A BREAK FROM THE PAST. Deleting what came before you in favor of â€œthe miraculous nowâ€â€¦ America wants to be a vacuum of time and space, a suspended hologram of perfection, unmolested by historyâ€” and unadulterated by nature. â€” Steven Phillips-Horst

+

The complaint that real humans â€œtalk in circles for hoursâ€ and engage with â€œsubjective nuanceâ€ reflects something all too real about our social skills in these times. As a society, weâ€™ve been socially deskilled in countless ways. The performance-based dynamics of social media, the biases and bigotries that divide us, and the loss of third spaces have eroded our capacity to relate to one another. â€” Kelly Hayes

+

[The phone] knows the parts of ourselves which we donâ€™t know, and cannot really understand the parts of ourselves which we are actually most interested in. â€” Aidan Walker

+

Beijing Watches Fake Sunrise On Video Screen Amid Smog Emergency (2014)

+

â€œTasted a little tear gasâ€” tasted like fascismâ€

â€œTasted a little tear gasâ€” tasted like fascismâ€ pic.twitter.com/o7SLl4ZWnV â€” Acyn (@Acyn) June 8, 2025

Thinking about how narrative can coopt â€” and eventually shape â€” reality in relation to the LA protests this week, and how they are being portrayed as chaos by the government and media when on-the-ground reports are that it was pretty chill till the cops showed up and started shooting people. It seems to make little difference what is true when Republicans can paint every act as a step towards the reality they desire. The troops did in fact get deployed to LA, whether or not it was legal or justified, law enforcement did in fact shoot peopleâ€¦ that those they shot were journalists!!! and protesters practicing their First Amendment rights means nothing when MAGA can handwave them off as paid insurgents (ğŸ¤¨ the critical thinking skills have been shut down here). The occupying administration is synthesizing a false â€œtruthâ€ from segments of reality that do not represent Truth.

The saying goes that â€œcinema is truth 24 times per second,â€ but the medium of film bears little relation to truth in itself, as the scene excludes whatever is cropped from the frame, the temporal context of events preceding and following, and all sensory elements besides sight and sound. Fact-checking the quote, I discovered it has a second part: â€œand every cut is a lie.â€ I finally read the Walter Benjamin essay ğŸ¦¾ and he writes that film inherently separates viewer from truth because of the camera intermediary: â€œHis creation is by no means all of a piece; it is composed of many separate performances.â€ Semblances of reality may be montaged together to create a seamless imitation of some desired reality.

See also:

Creating our own unrealities

Ceding the work of interpretation

Complementary: what is real?

On conformity and control

title: Electrifying my house: the first year with a heat pump â€“ Tracy Durnell's Mind Garden
content:
A year ago, we had our gas furnace and water heater replaced with a heat pump and electric water heater. They both really needed replacing. Weâ€™d hoped to have it done before the winter started since our furnace had already been on the fritz for several years â€” but the equipment was on backorder.

My energy utility, Puget Sound Energy (PSE), wants people to stay on gas, so there werenâ€™t incentives from them for this switch; however, my city developed a bulk purchase and incentive program to assist homeowners in transitioning to support the communityâ€™s climate goals. This upgrade electrified our whole house, so we could shut off our gas service!*

Now that Iâ€™ve had a heat pump for a year, I wanted to share my experience, because I had questions and misconceptions that I didnâ€™t get answered beforehand. Tl;dr itâ€™s great, especially the cooling, just works a little differently.

(Heads-up: 2500 word post, but itâ€™s got graphs! ğŸ¤©)

*Technically we still have a gas fireplace installed, but we never used it. PSE said it was safe to simply turn off even if that means there might be a small amount of gas remaining in the pipes under the house.

Why we got a heat pump

Our old setup was failing

Before the upgrade, we had a ~20 year old gas furnace and an old gas water heater. In November 2019, a pipe on our water heater ruptured, spraying a ton of scalding water into our garage ceiling, filling the entire garage with steam that we had to hire a company to install fans for days to dry out. After that, the furnace began to fail regularly, falsely tripping the safety shut-off and needing to be restarted multiple times a day. We had people out to fix it multiple times, but the most they could figure was that something inside was corroded and theyâ€™d clean it to buy us another few months.

My husbandâ€™s telecommuted for years, and during the pandemic, I started working from home too â€” but the only â€œcoolingâ€ we had was a ceiling fan in our living room and dining room. We bought a used portable electric window A/C unit to keep my husbandâ€™s office from turning into an inferno, and hefted it down the hall to our bedroom in the evenings. Less than ideal.

Natural gas is terrible for the planet and for people

â€œNatural gasâ€ is the greenwashed industry name for methane, an extremely potent greenhouse gas. A lot of methane is fracked, which may have impacts on the health of surrounding communities. Methane is piped, often through First Nation peopleâ€™s lands without permission â€” think Keystone XL and Canadaâ€™s Coastal GasLink pipeline â€” where it may leak and harm the water and ecosystem. Also, some methane leaks during fracking and distribution, contributing to emissions.

Moreover, â€œnatural gasâ€ is propped up by corporate propaganda that cooking with gas is better than electric, despite the atrocious impact methane has on indoor air quality and its contribution to household emissions. I have an electric stove, so I didnâ€™t have to replace mine in order to get off gas.

Without gas-burning appliances, our risk of carbon monoxide poisoning is lowered; it would come from some other source, like operating a propane stove indoors (DO NOT DO THAT THING). My husband knows someone who has brain damage from carbon monoxide poisoning!

Basically, â€œnatural gasâ€ is fucking shit and I want fucking nothing to do with it.

My new all-electric home energy setup

My house is about 1400s.f. and has two stories. It was built in the 1980s and our attic doesnâ€™t have enough insulation (weâ€™ve replaced insulation in the basement but not yet dealt with the attic).

Mitsubishi heat pump air handler (SVZ-KP24NA) â€” 24,000 BTU/hour

General Aire residential whole-house air cleaner (GFI #4422 or 4424)

Mitsubishi wall head (split-type air conditioner MSZ-GL15NA) â€” one unit installed on second floor â€” we considered a second but decided to save $$$



50-gallon electric water heater â€” the installer recommended against tankless despite what Iâ€™d read online ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸

18-panel / 5.04kW solar system (Itek IT280 photovoltaic modules and Itek Theia HEâ€t UL 3.8 kW inverter) â€” installed in 2015

The air handler connects to our existing duct system. Thereâ€™s the outdoor unit, which we placed on the side of the house directly below the upstairs heat pump head, and thereâ€™s also the air cleaner in the garage where the old furnace was.

The city bulk purchase program we went through offered Mitsubishi heat pumps, and we just went with what the contractor recommended.

How much did the heat pump and electric water heater cost?

I am located in the Seattle area, which has been in a housing boom for a while so contractors are pretty expensive.

The heat pump cost $19,445 + 10.2% tax for equipment and installation. The permit cost $236.*

The electric water heater with new dedicated 220v circuit cost $2,145 + 10.2% tax.

Our city provided a $500 incentive and coordinated a $1,200 discount for bulk purchase of equipment, so in total we paid $22,155 for both heat pump and new water heater.

*The permit included an inspection, which failed the first time â€” we wouldnâ€™t have known what wasnâ€™t installed quite right, so thanks inspector! He was super helpful and pointed out some other unrelated things he noticed that we might consider acting on.

Heat pump vs. gas furnace energy use comparisons

My situation will not be directly comparable to most peopleâ€™s because we have a solar array, but hopefully will still provide a relative comparison. I have provided the electricity we used, which includes power we generated and used directly, but not power we generated and sold back to PSE.

Unfortunately since we upgraded the water heater at the same time, we canâ€™t isolate only the cost of the heat pump ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸

Obnoxiously, our power bill comes mid-month. To make life easier for myself in the graphs, Iâ€™ve represented the month the bill was issued. That typically covers usage from the 18th of the previous month through the 17th of the billing month ğŸ˜•

Context: weather and energy trends in the Pacific Northwest

For usage context, in the Seattle area, itâ€™s relatively cool (and we run heating) from mid September through early June. Summer is usually relatively moderate, typically peaking with one or two weeks in the 90s (F). Over 100F is unusual.

How much more electricity did the heat pump use?

These data represent solely our electricity use, so you can guesstimate how much electricity we use for heating (and cooling) by how much our electricity increased after January 2023. During the cold months (December through March bills), we used about 1200-1500 additional kWh (for heating our space and water). Over the whole year, we used an additional 7300kWh compared to the previous year. (According to PSE, itâ€™s typical to use about 2800kWh annually for an electric water heater and 6800kWh for a heat pump, or 9600kWh annually.)

Youâ€™ll see that we had a big jump in electricity use in January 2024 (technically mid December through mid January). This coincides with an extremely cold snap for Washington, with temperatures in the ~19 degree Fahrenheit range for about a week. We didnâ€™t adjust our thermostat during that time period, but did run the heat pump head overnight as well as pulled out a small standalone electric space heater to help keep the house warmer during the day.

Monthly kWh electricity used, Sept. 16 2021-Jan. 17, 2024 Month 2021 2022 2023 2024 kWh difference

with heat pump 1 499 495 1946 1451 2 419 *1044 *625 3 545 1737 1192 4 681 1617 936 5 695 1120 425 6 531 993 462 7 1003 1213 210 8 1212 1059 -153 9 868 973 105 10 577 721 880 159 11 466 541 1274 733 12 430 500 1651 1151

bold = electric only â€” heat pump installed January 30, 2023

* About half the February 2023 billing cycle was on gas heat



How much methane usage did we eliminate?

In 2022, we used 770 therms of methane.* Now, we use none! ğŸ™Œ

*According to PSE, a typical house uses 690 therms for a gas furnace and 160 therms for a gas water heater, or 850 therms annually.

Comparing gas therms and kWh electricity

A therm is equal to approximately 29 kWh. Unless Iâ€™m being totally unreasonable in converting and combining these values, hereâ€™s how the overall kWh shakes out â€” a massive reduction in energy used with the heat pump (Feb 2023-Jan 2024):

How much did it cost to run the heat pump versus the gas furnace?

The first month we used the heat pump for cooling, I was braced for a radical energy bill, but thanks to our solar panels, we continued to pay the minimum electrical charge in summer ğŸ¦¾

In actual costs, we paid $1435 for energy (gas and electricity) in 2022 and $1158 in 2023 (heat pump only); if we assumed that the four summer months of 2022 were $7.95 as in a normal year, that would still put 2022 at $1215. And if we swapped in this yearâ€™s all-electric January bill for last yearâ€™s gas-heated bill, thatâ€™s basically a wash. And now we have whole-house cooling in summer ğŸ˜

Monthly energy bill by year, Sept. 16 2021-Jan. 17, 2024 Month 2021 2022 2023 2024 1 $218.41 *$229.79 $260.96 2 $158.67 $202.26 3 $148.30 $188.41 4 $108.26 $91.73 5 $79.85 $28.09 6 $51.67 $7.95 7 *$36.18 $7.95 8 *$76.16 $7.95 9 *$86.90 $7.95 10 $71.32 *$84.62 $46.02 11 $101.87 *$161.19 $136.05 12 $143.28 *$224.62 $204.68

bold = electric only â€” heat pump installed January 30, 2023

* = our solar inverter was not selling electricity back to PSE these months, though was generating power for pass-through usage â€” in a normal year the summer month costs would be the minimum $7.95 â€” this also means there was no bank to draw from for those fall and winter months

What I wish weâ€™d known before switching to a heat pump

It heats differently than a gas furnace: slow and steady versus bursts of heat

The first month we had our heat pump, in the cold of February 2023, I was convinced it was broken or weâ€™d been sold too small of a unit. If you go in with expectations that itâ€™s going to be a different heating experience than a gas furnace, youâ€™ll be happier than I was at first ğŸ˜‰

Being used to a gas furnace, we were used to saying, â€œItâ€™s cold!â€ and bumping the thermostat* up a couple degrees, then getting the immediate feedback of a big blast of hot air and a relatively quick increase in temperature.

In contrast, the heat pump blows air lightly all day long**. If we increase the thermostat setting, it will take several hours to reach the new temperature. Likewise, when itâ€™s too cold out, sometimes it has a hard time keeping up. (Iâ€™m hoping that upping our attic insulation will help hold the temperature better.)

*We had a Nest before, but I donâ€™t think it actually helped save energy since we were home all day every day, so between that and Googleâ€™s creepy surveillance I was fine when I found out the heat pump came with a thermostat and wouldnâ€™t work with the Nest. Unfortunately, the included thermostat is kind of annoying to program.

**Because heat pumps blow constantly, the contractor recommended keeping as many vents open as possible â€” closing no more than one or two. (There was a technical reason for this that I forget, something about making part of the heat pump get too cold and shut down.) Unfortunately, whoever installed our original HVAC system was, er, clearly the low bidder, so we have wacky vents directly underneath windows and doors all over the house ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸ The register that blows the hottest is our downstairs bathroom ğŸ™„

So, with the heat pump, we donâ€™t drop the temperature overnight as much as we did with the gas furnace. We keep the house a more consistent temperature all the time. Then, the poor heat pump isnâ€™t always struggling to keep up, it just holds what itâ€™s got.

The heads arenâ€™t as quiet as theyâ€™re made out to be

Whoever says theyâ€™re basically silent hasnâ€™t paid much attention. The heat pump head (which is in our bedroom) makes mysterious noises pretty often, particularly when in heating mode*. My poor cat Mina stares at it, transfixed in horror, as it tinkles like broken glass going through the wash, whooshes like the house is blasting off, brrrs to life unexpectedly, and whirs as the louvers rotate up and down randomly. It sometimes makes noise even when the unit is turned off, which is confusing.

The fan noises are relatively quiet, especially in comparison with a window AC unit, so thatâ€™s probably the frame of reference people have when they talk about it being silent. But itâ€™s not silent if youâ€™re changing from forced air, which actually is basically silent ğŸ˜‰ Overall, itâ€™s not too intrusive and totally worth it for being able to fine-tune the comfort level of our bedroom, but not quite what I had anticipated.

*I am pretty sensitive to noise, but my husband and cats agree on this one ğŸ˜‰

Our verdict: the heat pump is a huge win for summer, good for winter

It kicks ass in summer

Wow, after previously not having cooling in summer, it was incredible to be able to comfortably use my office after like 3pm in the summer ğŸ˜‚ I was especially the beneficiary because in the past my husband got the portable A/C unit since his office was hotter.

The heat pump couldnâ€™t keep up with the hottest days in the high nineties, but even then still kept the house in comfortable mid to high eighties â€” totally fine for us, especially with a ceiling fan.

Good in normal cold, fine in cold cold

Once we learned how to program the thermostat appropriately, weâ€™ve been happy with how the heat pump keeps the house warm.

Iâ€™ll be honest: this thing struggles with the cold cold (below freezing). From my understanding, actually cold places use a backup furnace IIRC, but the temperatureâ€™s generally moderate enough in Seattle that we get by with just a heat pump and suck it up for the one or two extra-cold weeks a year.

During our recent cold snap, when it was 16 degrees Fahrenheit overnight one night, the house was 55 degrees when we went downstairs in the morning despite the thermostat being set to 68. It didnâ€™t heat up much during the morning, so we pulled out our little electric space heater and an electric heating pad to boost the warmth, and bundled up with down vests and blankets. This is where the heat pump head is key: we were able to keep our bedroom, where the head is located, comfortable overnight (though we did add extra blankets).

And honestly? The heat pumpâ€™s so much more efficient, better for the climate, and safer for us that wearing a jacket for a week or two in the winter seems like a totally reasonable tradeoff.

I had a blast visiting five gardens around the Juanita neighborhood ğŸ˜ƒ There were 12 gardens on the tour but I think youâ€™d be hard-pressed to see them all! I started at 11 and was wiped by 2:30 so I didnâ€™t push myself to squeeze in one more.

â€œChampagne Creekâ€

â€œBloomâ€

We have collected seeds and plants from Tibet, Europe and elsewhere and enjoy a very English style profusion with lawn and intertwined stairs and hidden trails.â€ (This garden was very much my vibe.)

Takeaways

Itâ€™s lovely to see stunning gardens like these, but also having paid for landscaping, I have to distinguish between what someone could accomplish with many tens of thousands of dollars of hardscaping and what could be adaptable to my yard. Some of the gardens leaned on sweat equity and cleverness, which is what my budget calls for ğŸ˜‰ Boulders are $$$ as much as I love how they look ğŸ¥º (Our landscape plan originally called for a fountain but the landscaper wasnâ€™t willing to wait for electricity to be trenched, since it would need an inspection, even though they saw the plans when we got the quote ğŸ™„ so, we have a bird bath)

I think some cheapish landscaping cobblestones, metal arches, and more yard art could go a fair ways to adding finish to my garden. I also suspect another couple Japanese maples could pull things together. title: Back to â€œnormalâ€ â€“ Tracy Durnell's Mind Garden
content:
Not to pick on this person, itâ€™s a funny protest sign â€” but it seems like a lot of people are thinking like weâ€™re in a â€œone weird trickâ€ (impeachment) scenario and, once we get that done, weâ€™ll magically return to some type of â€œnormalâ€ and we can all go homeâ€¦ but the concept of normality is doing some heavy lifting here.

What â€œnormalâ€ looks like

Itâ€™s normal for minimum wage to stay the same for decades.

Itâ€™s normal that people earning low wages must work multiple jobs and often still qualify for food stamps.

Itâ€™s normal that billionaires exist when low-paid workers have to decide between the power bill and paying the rent.

Itâ€™s normal that disabled people effectively cannot marry, since theyâ€™ll often lose access to government support.

Itâ€™s normal to use prisoners as slave labor (or close enough to it with hourly â€œwagesâ€ of pennies).

Itâ€™s normal that immigrants from some countries must wait decades to become citizens because of arbitrary caps.

Itâ€™s normal to let immigrants get paid less and treated worse in tech jobs because theyâ€™re trapped by H1B visa requirements.

Itâ€™s normal that *everyone* in America is to some extent trapped in their job because healthcare is ruinously expensive.

Itâ€™s normal that Americans die of preventable disease for lack of money.

Itâ€™s normal that women donâ€™t get to choose what medical treatment they receive if they are pregnant.

Itâ€™s normal to address gun violence by blaming mental health but not increasing funding to expand access.

Itâ€™s normal to â€œsolveâ€ homelessness by throwing away all of someoneâ€™s worldly possessions and putting them on a one-way bus out of town.

Itâ€™s normal that kids go hungry at lunch.

Itâ€™s normal that Puerto Ricans and people from D.C. are denied congressional representation.

Itâ€™s normal that 70- and 80-year-olds hold most of the political power in the country, and people under 40 very little.

Itâ€™s normal to hand over all our personal data to megacorporations who run extensive systems of surveillance that they share with law enforcement.

Itâ€™s normal that the government spies on its own citizens.

Itâ€™s normal that hundreds of people die in car crashes daily.

Itâ€™s normal that our spaces are built for cars, not people, and driving is often the only way to get around.

Itâ€™s normal that the US government doesnâ€™t honor its treaties with Tribes.

Itâ€™s normal that we supply Israel with funding while they enact genocide.

Itâ€™s normal that our water rights system is so terrible, and our water use so excessive, that the Colorado River no longer reaches the Gulf of California.

Itâ€™s normal that downstream communities must bear the health burdens and costs of upstream industrial polluters.

Thinking bigger than just getting out of this

â€œNormalâ€ fucking sucks. Outright fascism is worse, but there are plenty of things we need to change. Kat Abughazaleh, whoâ€™s running for office in Illinois, says:

â€œThereâ€™s no reason every American should not be able to afford housing, groceries, health insurance, public transit (ideally), and then still have enough money to save and take your kid to the zoo or go to the movies with your friends. Thereâ€™s just, thereâ€™s no reason â€” we are the wealthiest country in the world. The idea that thatâ€™s unrealistic or idealistic or naive or even called childish, I think thatâ€™s sucky.â€

We donâ€™t have to settle for returning to a normal that sucks â€” but protest may not be enough to force change. Our current situation has been the Republican gameplan for decades; we will not escape it by liberating ourselves from a single politician. Trump is a symptom, but the rot runs much deeper. We need to reckon emotionally with the long fights ahead; protests alone will not solve our problems. Iâ€™m not saying protest isnâ€™t helpful or important â€” Iâ€™m saying that we need to find space for both brunch and advocacy in our lives. Micah L. Sifry writes:

One of the most inspiring ways that pro-democracy movements grow their strength is by inventing and spreading ways for the silent majority to make itself both visible and influential.

Iâ€™ve been seeing organizers talking about the need to transform the current energy into long-term work, and not let it fizzle out. Jared Yates Sexton describes the way that authorities rein in public speech:

We are, according to those who want nothing more than to maintain control, supposed to protest enough, but not too much. Because we should rely on them. Because we need to maintain our subservient position under the party as opposed to in conversation and discourse with the party.

One strategy: focusing on local advocacy and building up

My pet theory is that most people should spend their advocacy time supporting local (and state) efforts, and donate to organizations advocating at the federal level. The collapse of local news and intense media focus on national politics encourages people to feel powerless because at the federal level most of what you can do is harass your senator. It also frames politics as something â€œyou doâ€ once every four years for normies, every two years for the passionate, every election for the wonks and zealots. If you get people involved in local politics, I imagine that get-out-the-vote drives become a lot easier because people are already tuned in.

The local level is more influential than people realize, I suspect. In Washington State, how environmental policies often play out is that they get implemented at either King County or City of Seattle first, then several suburban cities, and then thereâ€™s a model and coalition for building a state-level policy. As former city staff, I can say itâ€™s no accident it works this way â€” we knew our colleagues at other cities and would learn from each other, sharing lessons and draft policy language. Regional organizations support, both partnering with cities and going down to Olympia during the legislative session to advocate for (and against) bills. We know that Republicans followed a similar model in the evil direction in red states, building up a portfolio of harmful policies to bring to the federal level in the form of Project 2025â€¦ why donâ€™t we do the same for progressive policies?

If we start thinking and working now, we can set things up for the next state legislative session, then the next federal election, then the presidential election. (Iâ€™m not going down rabbitholes about martial law, I donâ€™t find it helpful to indulge in that kind of despairing fatalism â€” I think my personal work on managing catastrophic thinking and anxiety has paid dividends here.)

I havenâ€™t decided what bigger thing I want to work on yetâ€¦ for now Iâ€™ve just been doing ad hoc advocacy when itâ€™s pointed out by the urbanist Discord server Iâ€™m in. Iâ€™m pissed that Washington had a school lunch bill that failed in the legislative session, so potentially supporting another run at thatâ€¦ or badgering the governor about Washingtonâ€™s regressive taxation policy and demanding an income tax on the wealthiest Washingtonians, which he put the kibosh on this budget cycle and was why the budget was too tight to feed kids ğŸ™„ Come on, Bob! We have a lot of tech companies â€” and tech CEOs â€” here who could stand to pay their fair share. Or I could go harder on supporting housing; I just looked at King Countyâ€™s affordable housing dashboard, which identifies a need for 44,000 affordable units by 2024, and THE ENTIRE SEATTLE AREA HAD BUILT FEWER THAN FIVE THOUSAND UNITS by 2022. *screaming*

Organizing coalitions

Iâ€™m also spinning on the provocation of the second method of organizing described in the Win the Midwestâ€™s 10-year report (emphasis mine):

There are two approaches to base building. We can ask what we are for, and then go out and find the people who agree with us. Or we can begin by asking who we need to organize in order to build enough power to shift everything, and then go where they are: workplaces, churches, mosques, synagogues, schools, and childcare centers. Grassroots organizations that meet people where they are â€“ physically and ideologically â€“ and that create spaces of belonging, learning, and formation rooted in peopleâ€™s lives and experiences have an unlimited number of people to organize. Most people do not have clearly defined political outlooks, but they can move into public leadership roles. Organizations willing to put their base at the center of their plans can co-create a political agenda that emerges from the lived experience of their bases.

Iâ€™m an extremely opinionated person, and I know what outcomes I want (though Iâ€™d rather listen to others on the best tactics on achieving those outcomes), but maybe I could think of this as prioritizing which outcomes to focus on based on which ones enough other people also want and will fight for. L.A. Kauffman discusses building coalitions with those we disagree with, quoting a 1981 talk / 1983 essay â€œCoalition Politics: Turning the Centuryâ€:

â€œThe reason we are stumbling,â€ Dr. [Bernice] Reagon declared all those years ago, â€œis that we are at the point where in order to take the next step weâ€™ve got to do it with some folk we donâ€™t care too much about. And we got to vomit over that for a little while. We must just keep going.â€

Further reading:

Why Do Anything? by Dj Bracken â€” this guy decided to start paying down student lunch debt in Utah, and eventually helped get a statewide bill passed (I was loosely involved in supporting new â€œshare tablesâ€ / fridges at our local elementary schools, AMA)

From Aspiration to Action: Organizing Through Exhaustion, Grief, and Uncertainty by Kelly Hayes

See also:

Donâ€™t let them say itâ€™s normal

Extending my understanding of self-care

Being a citizen means taking ownership

title: Creating rituals: remembering Coach Taylor â€“ Tracy Durnell's Mind Garden
content:
My high school track and cross country coach Mr. Taylor was a master at creating rituals and culture. A former seminary student who was obsessed with ancient Greece, he started each practice with a philosophy discussion. He wove in, too, tales of past runners and triumphs â€” heâ€™d been coach for nearly thirty years already â€” creating our own pantheon of heroes, the teamâ€™s own mythos. Who of us would one day join its ranks?

Mr. Taylor recognized how much the mind and body are connected. He treated our labor seriously, and expected us to do the same. Excellence â€” arÃªte â€” was our goal. Iâ€™ll admit that plenty of times I tuned out the talk, but there was something about sitting down as a team to transition from school to sport, using that time to mentally prepare for the physical work.

One of my favorite rituals was to honor outgoing seniors on the cross-country team. At the final home race of the season, each senior released one of his homing pigeons. (I was annoyed because I had to share a pigeon ğŸ˜‚) As far as I can remember, there was no special meaning to this, it just was a thing that he made happen each year. A created ceremony we nonetheless looked forward to; simply having some marker, however arbitrary, gave the season an emotional culmination beyond the final race, recognition of our contributions to the team regardless of how we placed.

He built the teamâ€™s culture through these shared rites and rituals, building a sense of continuity with past runners both at our school and at the origins of track in Ancient Greece.

I canâ€™t talk about ritual and Mr. Taylor without also talking about ArÃªte West. Starting in 1979, every other year he took a group of about eight students from the track or cross country team to Greece. At first, they went to compete, but over the years it shifted into more of a philosophical journey and extended into greater Europe. Over the course of twenty trips, the experience developed its own rituals. (I went on trip thirteen.)

The first: secret invitation. My best friend hounded me, but I wouldnâ€™t confess that Iâ€™d received The Postcard telling me when and where our first meeting would be. (We met every other week throughout the school year to study and prepare for the trip.) We all showed up that first night unsure who the seven other voyagers would be. In my year, the eighth person no-showed â€” we never found out who else had been invited and declined to join.

The trip itself teemed with rituals. My least favorite involved running through the hot, dusty Greek countryside to an ancient track where we were expected to take off our shoes and run a lap in bare feet, like the runners of old. On Ithaca, we ran, separately, to â€œTelemachosâ€™ beachâ€. In Delphi, we were meant to sleep in â€œthe meadowâ€ where many past Arete trips had slept (but he couldnâ€™t find it in the twilight, so we slept on a random dirt road ğŸ˜’ Apparently on my sisterâ€™s trip there was a dead dog in the meadow and they said no fucking way).

Mr. Taylor believed strongly in the power of place and designed the experience to provoke encounters with meaning. (Some more successful than othersâ€¦) I lugged my clarinet across Europe so I could play Mozartâ€™s clarinet concerto outside the building where he died (?). Everywhere we went, one or another of us had been assigned topics to present on or locations to give a reading. (I botched my reading from The Agony and The Ecstasy at the Vatican and read a passage about the wrong Michaelangelo Mother and Child sculpture ğŸ¤£) Overlooking the Acropolis, one of the boys had to read us Periclesâ€™s funeral speech, as each trip had done before us. In Sils Maria, we walked in Nietzscheâ€™s footsteps and discussed quotes at various waypoints along the trail. Our trip was our own, yet inextricably linked with previous trips through shared touchstones and repeated experiences: rituals meant to connect us to the past, both modern and ancient.

This is my contribution to the August IndieWeb Blog Carnival, hosted by Steve Ledlow on the theme of ritual.
